newsitem.title: USA: IMM currencies end mixed ahead of Tankan, holiday.
newsitem.headline: IMM currencies end mixed ahead of Tankan, holiday.

text.p: IMM currency futures finished mixed in a recovery from early losses as the focus turned to the upcoming Tankan report and the U.S. Thanksgiving holiday.
Japan's report of business sentiment will be released on Wednesday before the U.S. markets open. Traders said December yen and dollar/yen were rangebound on Tuesday ahead of that report.

"That's as to be expected in front of this holiday," one IMM trader said. "But a lot of traders won't be manning desks tomorrow at all and I think that this could really make for some volatility for this Tankan report," he said.
IMM currencies will close early on Wednesday and Friday at 1200 CST/1800 GMT and will not trade on Thursday in observance of that U.S. holiday.
Traders said the combination of the holiday and the Tankan could keep action choppy and possibly volatile into next week.

"I'm really expecting dollar/yen to spike higher, like to 114.75," the currency trader said. He said the general trend of the dollar was upward, and said unless the Tankan shows a huge change for the better in Japan's economy, the dollar uptrend will continue. December yen support was seen at $0.008875 and $0.008806, the contract low settlement.

In Tuesday's action, the dollar came off its highs near midday and retreated to more familiar ground after rallies in dollar/mark and dollar/Swiss Monday and early Tuesday. Traders said players were likely positioning ahead of the holiday.
December marks and Swiss francs closed up from their earlier lows but still lower, lagging from early evidence that the Swiss banking sector was being hurt by a weak economy there.
Standard & Poor's announced on Tuesday it had placed triple-A long-term rated Union Bank of Switzerland on credit watch.
S&P said its "CreditWatch" action follows UBS' announcement that it will record a SFr 0.5 billion loss in 1996.

Traders tied some currency strength to a midday sell-off in U.S. stocks. They said the stock reversal put a crimp on the dollar's bullishness and could continue to stem dollar gains if stocks see an extended correction.

December yen settled up $0.000007 at $0.008906, marks slipped $0.0008 to $0.6566, Swiss francs were $0.0016 lower at $0.7762, sterling rose $0.0026 to $1.6706, Canadian dollars were up $0.0001 at $0.7462, Australian dollars were down $0.0003 at $0.8099 and Mexican pesos were up $0.000450 at $0.125400. -Derivatives desk 312-408-8750;E-mail derivatives@reuters.com
